results.title: Toupie-fantoche (Spinning Top)
results.brief_description: Charles-Émile Reynaud wasn’t content with only inventing the praxinoscope. In 1881 he simplified his own design, creating a new portable optical toy called the toupie-fantoche, or ‘spinning top’. Typical scenes included butterflies fluttering, dogs jumping through hoops and drummer boys drumming.

constellations_primary.name: Reflecting duality and revealing new realities
constellations_primary.description: The Toupie Fantoche relies on four prismatic mirrors to reflect changes in animation states.

results.description: Charles-Émile Reynaud wasn’t content with only inventing the praxinoscope. In 1881 he simplified his own design, creating a new portable optical toy called the toupie-fantoche, or ‘spinning top’. The toupie-fantoche consisted of a handle and a pyramid lined with mirrors at 45 degrees that reflected sequential images on a disc above. When the spinning top rotated, the rapid succession of illustrations gave the impression of one moving image. Typical scenes included butterflies fluttering, dogs jumping through hoops and drummer boys drumming.
description_for_label: Charles-Émile Reynaud wasn’t content with only inventing the praxinoscope. In 1881 he simplified his own design, creating a new portable optical toy called the toupie-fantoche, or ‘spinning top’. The toupie-fantoche consisted of a handle and a pyramid lined with mirrors at 45 degrees that reflected sequential images on a disc above. When the spinning top rotated, the rapid succession of illustrations gave the impression of one moving image. Typical scenes included butterflies fluttering, dogs jumping through hoops and drummer boys drumming.

results.title: Toast
results.brief_description: “Humour is a universal language,” says Edie Kurzer, and it’s an element she weaves into much of her artistic output. It’s also something that attracted her to the unique portraiture work of Sydney artist Heather Mitchell. Better known for her stage and screen presence, Mitchell has found a growing audience for her toast portraits of Australian celebrities in her medium of choice: Vegemite. Creating these slices especially for our display, she has shone a tasty spotlight on some of our most singular screen faces such as Josh Thomas, Lee Lin Chin, Deborah Mailman and others.

constellations_other.name: Ladies who own the narrative
constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

results.description: “Humour is a universal language,” says Edie Kurzer, and it’s an element she weaves into much of her artistic output. It’s also something that attracted her to the unique portraiture work of Sydney artist Heather Mitchell. Better known for her stage and screen presence, Mitchell has found a growing audience for her toast portraits of Australian celebrities in her medium of choice: Vegemite. Creating these slices especially for our display, she has shone a tasty spotlight on some of our most singular screen faces such as Josh Thomas, Lee Lin Chin, Deborah Mailman and others.
description_for_label: “Humour is a universal language,” says Edie Kurzer, and it’s an element she weaves into much of her artistic output. It’s also something that attracted her to the unique portraiture work of Sydney artist Heather Mitchell. Better known for her stage and screen presence, Mitchell has found a growing audience for her toast portraits of Australian celebrities in her medium of choice: Vegemite. Creating these slices especially for our display, she has shone a tasty spotlight on some of our most singular screen faces such as Josh Thomas, Lee Lin Chin, Deborah Mailman and others.

group_works.title: Toast art

results.title: Tinted film
results.brief_description: The most common methods of colouring early films were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre, while toning was adapted from photographic printing.

constellations_primary.name: Monsters, murder and mystery
constellations_primary.description: Murder and mystery hide in the shadows born from German Expressionism.

results.description: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.
description_for_label: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.

results.title: Thunder Mountain cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Fox Film Corporation and David Howard
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: Red-blooded adventure and colourful romance in this zane grey thrilling story of the west. George O’Brien in Thunder Mountain with Barbara Fritchie Frances Grant for general admission
